column4: hi. On ubuntu 10.04 my init.d scripts are not starting (e.g. apache2, tomcat6). They do run OK with service apache2 start, but not on boot. The symlinks are correctly set on the rcx.d dirs, and rc.conf exists in upstart /etc/init dir... what else can be happening!
Are there scripts in upstart directory of /etc/init for them instead?
nope, no upstart scripts, only sys v... but they should be running, don't they?
Yes, by way of the etc/init/rc-sysinit.conf  ..are these init.d scripts "factory" or ones you made manually or perhaps with update-rc.d ?
If you made them manually, check they are +x
they look factory, as per comparision with another 10.04 which works ok, and in both cases +x is NOT set for rc-sysinit.conf
The /etc/init.d/<tomcat-or-other-sysv-script>   is what to check , not the rc-sysinit.conf
yes, sorry, they are factory and have +x and owner root:root
and in /etc/rc2.d I have the shortcuts
... generated by update-rc
Is there anything in /var/log/boot.log ?
( or logs with the names of the failed daemons in /var/log/upstart )
in boot.log only a fsck result
in /var/log/apache2 there are the usual apache logs with usual contents (i.e. after started with service apache2 start)
Anything informative in the apache2 log?
normal logs in both access.log and error.log up to the shutdown (in error log it logs about SIGTERM) all this in .1 files, and then the new log starting with the manual service start
the services are not even attempted to start I think
Very odd.
any other log you can think of?
in any case many thanks for your help
Offhand not anything I can think of to check. Did they work previously ? If so, what was the last thing you did before they stopped, etc ( upgrade, network tinkering, hardware replacement, etc )

this is a somewhat "inherited" server so... I don't know really, I'm not supposed to check this stuff but I'm the one affected first when the services don't start :) I checked that all looks normal, even compared files by the byte with my local machine (exactly the same 10.04) and all looks normal... really annoying...
where are startup failures logged... maybe something is failing before the scripts or somehitng
Might want to check daemon.log if you have it
